column1: Nen Hithoel was a large lake upon the Great River Anduin amid the Emyn Muil to the east of Rohan. The lake was approximately 20 miles long from north to south
column2: and 10 miles wide. The lake was formed by a narrow southern outlet and the small island of Tol Brandir
column3: which created a natural dam. Upon the lakes northern approach from Anduin the Men of Gondor carved the huge pillars of the Argonath in the reign of Rómendacil II to mark the northern boundary of their realm
column4: although by the time of the War of the Ring that boundary has long since receded. At the southern end of the lake stood three steep hills. Amon Hen
column6: was upon the western shore and Amon Lhaw
column8: was upon the east. The third hill formed the island of Tol Brandir. None ever set foot upon the island due to its sheer cliffs that rose directly from the river.

column1: The Fellowship of the Ring arrived at Nen Hithoel on 25 February
column3: and made camp at Parth Galen close to Amon Hen. The fall of Boromir and the breaking of the Fellowship occurred soon after. Frodo Baggins and Samwise Gamgee took a boat for the eastern shore skirting the southern edge of Tol Brandir
column4: Meriadoc Brandybuck and Peregrin Took were captured by Orcs
column5: and after sending Boromirs body over the falls in another boat
column9: set out to track the Orcs and find the captive Hobbits.
